frameDefinitions: This frame describes assembly or construction actions, where an Agent joins Components together to form a Created_entity, which is profiled, and hence the object of the verb.

The Becoming_detached frame covers two situations: a scene in which one thing comes to be physically detached from something else; or a scene in which two things come to be disconnected from each other.
A Signatory signs an Agreement document, thereby taking on a commitment encoded in the Agreement.  '.
An Author creates a Text, either written, such as a letter, or spoken, such as a speech,  that contains meaningful linguistic tokens, and may have a particular Addressee in mind.
A person (Speaker) expresses a Message or mental content, broadly understood, in a particular Manner.
A Speaker realizes a Sign, usually a linguistic one, in some Formal_realization.
frameExamples: Jack <t>built</t> a new house out of bricks.
The ship became <t>decoupled</t> from the dock.
. During this time, 84 countries (including the United States) <t>signed</t> the Protocol.
I <t>penned</t> a letter concerning racism to Congress.
A person doesn't always <t>pronounce</t> a word the way they say  it in context
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Agent</fen> builds a <fen>Created_entity</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Components</fen> that form the <fen>Created_entity</fen>.
<fen>Created_entity</fen> identifies the entity that is created in the act of building.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the building occurs.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the building occurs.
This role identifies the <fen>Item</fen> that detaches from the <fen>Source</fen>.
<fen>Source</fen> identifies the location to which an <fen>Item</fen> was attached before getting detached.

This role identifies the plural <fen>Items</fen> that are becoming detached from each other, resulting in their separation.


Notice that when the role <fen>Items</fen> occurs, neither <fen>Item</fen> nor <fen>Source</fen> can occur.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Item</fen> becomes detached from the <fen>Source</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the <fen>Item</fen>  becomes detached.
The signatory of the <fen>Agreement</fen>.
The entity signifying the identity of the <fen>Signatory</fen>, resulting from the act of writing on the <fen>Agreement</fen> document.
The document which encodes the commitment of the <fen>Signatory</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> at which signature is given.
The place where the signing occurs.
The <fen>Author</fen> produces a particular <fen>Text</fen>.
The entity which results from the act of writing or speaking.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> at which the text is created.
Where the event takes place.
<fen>Speaker</fen>, the person who encodes the <fen>Message</fen>, occurs as the External Argument of all the verbs:
The <fen>Message</fen> is almost invariably expressed in an NP Object. (The only exceptions occur with the verb <t>express</t>, which is occasionally used with that-clause complements.)

For most of the words in this frame, some expression of <fen>Manner</fen> or <fen>Medium</fen> is obligatory. As in other frames, <fen>Manner</fen> expressions characterize the action (in this case, the speech act performed by the <fen>Speaker</fen>). However, a wide range of <fen>Manner</fen> expressions occurs in this frame, including the following types:
<fen>Medium</fen> expresses the <fen>Medium</fen> of communication, such as the language used or the specific type of text in which the <fen>Message</fen> occurs:
The language user who produces a <fen>Sign</fen> in some modality.
An abstract form-meaning pairing.
An evaluation of whether the <fen>Formal_realization</fen> that the <fen>Speaker</fen> produced matches the standard or standard range.
The written string, gesture, or vocalized sound sequence that the <fen>Speaker</fen> produces.
A constituent part of the <fen>Formal_realization</fen>.
The way that the <fen>Speaker</fen> produces the <fen>Formal_realization</fen>.
The time when the <fen>Speaker</fen> produces the <fen>Formal_realization</fen>.
listRoleExamples: <fex>Jack</fex> built a new house.
Jack built  a new house <fex>out of old bricks</fex>.
Jack built <fex>a new house</fex>.
Jack built a new house <fex>early in the morning</fex>.
Jack built a new house <fex>in a glade</fex>.
<fex>Eisenhower</fex> signed a treaty  with aliens.
The Attorney General seemingly never put his <fex>signature</fex> on the agreement.
I signed <fex>the contract</fex> and now the dealership claims they made a mistake, quoted the price too low and now I have to pay them more money.
Michael wrote <fex>a frame description</fex>.
<fex>The teacher</fex> phrased the question carefully.
The Prime Minister expressed <fex>her sympathy for the victims</fex>.
True Manner: You should phrase it <fex>carefully</fex>.
Kim formulated her objections <fex>in French</fex>.
<fex>He</fex> insists on mispronouncing my name every time, the bastard!
My little nephew can't say <fex>prestidigitation</fex>
Finally, I would pay more attention to your 'oppinion' if you spelled it <fex>correctly</fex>.
The old uncensored editions of the Talmud referred to Jesus as Yeshua censored versions spelled it <fex>as Yeshu</fex>
You spelled it <fex>with a 't'</fex>.
You spelled it <fex>the way it sounds</fex>.
<fex>Today</fex> you spelled it 'pjuok'.
